United States Commercial Agency
St Paul de Loanda 25th November 1865.

div1.p:
In my despatch No 13, I had the honor of informing the Department that an American Seaman calling himself Edward Baxter, presented himself to me, on the 24th of September, requesting protection as a destitute seaman. He represented to me that he departed from the American Barque "Governor Carver" Captain Charles Mason of Westport, R.I. at Mossamedes (Little Fish Bay) for the reason that said Barque had taken in at that place slaves and that he assisted taking on board the first seventy five and on returning for more, ran away and after the Barque had proceeded to sea, he came down to the town and made arrangements with Captain of the British Mail Steamer "Lincolnshire" and came to this place and presented himself to me, as stated. I listened to his
Hon William H Seward Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
his story with apprehension and doubt, but not wishing to show, that I entertained such a feeling, I treated the subject, for a time with seeming indifference, and set Baxter to work, about my house with some light jobs. My anxiety to sift out the truth of this case increased from day to day and I questioned and cross-questioned him frequently on the subject with a view to compare one statement with another and I was surprised to find them always correspond. On one of these days, I met at the house of a friend, Watson Vredenburg Esquire, H B M's Commissioner for the Slave trade. We conversed together and I promised to send Baxter to him, that he might take his deposition, with an object to compare with the one that I should require of him, when I should consider it proper to take a formal one, before me. I sent Baxter to Mr Vredenburg, and to my surprise, two days after, I learned at a late hour that Baxter had been sent on board the British Brig "Elizabeth," as a British subject, and which vessel was that day sail for England. I was still under excitement on account of this extraordinary occurrence. Captain of
of the Portuguese Corvette "Infanto D. João" came into my office, and in a few words I explained to him the course of my . He made a remark of dissatisfaction and said he could not imagine what motive could have caused Mr Vredenburg to act so, and doubted very much if Baxter had been properly cleared by the Police Authorities, according to the local laws of this Province. I that same evening to learn that through Commander de D's influence Baxter was taken out of the vessel by order of the Police Authorities for not having been cleared from that department and sent on board of the Portuguese Corvette "Infanto D. João." Two days afterwards Baxter was sent to the British Consul (Mr Vredenburg is also Consul) on the 9th ult. I addressed a note to Mr Vredenburg, who immediately sent Baxter to my office with a despatch and a certified copy of the deposition of Baxter, taken before him. In the mean time the Portuguese Government had heard of the report made by Baxter of an embarcation of slaves in a Portuguese port, and addressed me a note requesting me the kindness to inform
inform them fully on the subject. The following evening, I invited three witnesses to my house and before them, took the deposition of Baxter and the same day sent a despatch to the Colonial Secretary General & other certified copies of both depositions. I also addressed Mr Vredenburg again. You will observe by inclosure No 6 that I requested of the Provincial Government to send Baxter to Mossamedes, as I thought that on the very spot they would be better able to get at the truth of this subject. I received a reply in the affirmative and on the 12th ult. I sent Baxter with a despatch, on board of the Portuguese Corvette "Infanto D. João". On the 14th ulto I received a despatch from the British Consul. On the 30th ulto the Corvette returned, and on that day I received a communication from Commander de D and on the 3rd inst a despatch from the acting Governor General both informing me that the evidence obtained at Mossamedes found Baxter guilty of basest falsehood and that he had been committed to Prison by order of the Government, to be tried on the charge of the false . I replied on the 3rd inst requesting
requesting copies of the depositions taken at Mossamedes In the meantime Baxter was brought up before the provincial Authorities for indictment when he confessed voluntarily that everything he had said was false and a I was officially informed of this fact on the 9th inst, enclosing Enclosure No. 14 me a certified copy of the confession taken before the Chief Enclosure No. 15 Justice of the City in open court. His Excellency in reply to my despatch (enclosure No 18) regretted that the original desposition taken at Mossamedes had been sent to the Judicial Authorities to enable them to find a bill of indictment against Baxter which prevented him sending me copies at present adding that they were very voluminous and not of much importance after the declaration of falsehood made by him. I was satisfied that the evidence was quite sufficient and on the 11th inst. I addressed a note to the President of the Government Council Enclosure No. 20 expressing my approval in complimentary terms on the favorable termination of this case which at one time indicated serious alarm, on the probable revival of the slave trade in American vessels
vessels and in Portuguese waters. On the 20th instant I addressed a note of congratulations and thanks to Commander Vargas de O of the Portuguese CorvetteInfanto de Soao and also to Fernando de Casta Seal Governor of Mossamedes. I also wrote on the same date to Charles Mason, Master of the Barque "Governor Carver" requesting him when he visited Mossamedes to call at this port. Throughout the case a spirited correspondence had been carried on between the British Consul and the President of the Government Council, on account of the Authorities having taken Baxter from on board the Brig "Elizabeth" and question their authority to do so, alleging that they interfered with his Consular functions. The Government has endeavoured to convince him that they acted in accordance with the local laws of this Province. The President of the Government Council told me he had censured him for not regarding one or more persons the responsibility which the accusation of Baxter inflcited upon the reputation of Portugal and the United States and without entertaining the least consideration would have sent Baxter to the Foreign Office
Office in England and thereby compromise the Provincial Government and the Commercial Agency of the United States. The Provincial Government has also been informed by the British Consul that Baxter was a British subject and prepared to have delivered him over to me as a deserter from an American Barque. The Department will observe by the several deportations that Baxter declared himself, on oath, to be an American naturalized citizen. In his confession which can be taken as a "bona fide" evidence he further declared that he is a naturalized citizen of the United States. He claimed protection at this Commercial Agency when he could have applied to the British Consulate and being also a deserter from the American Barque "Governor Carver" I felt fully authorized with all these facts to send upon him my Consular authority. By enclosure No 1 you will perceive that I expressed my surprise to the British Consul at his attempting to send Baxter to England when he had no reason to suppose that I had done with him. Baxter was commanded to
to present himself to the Foreign Office on his arrival on England, to be there questioned on the subject and the consequences of such a step without the possibility of contra-evidence should have been extremely serious. He offered me an apology for acting thus, alleging that he supposed I had done with him but which I had never thought a justifiable excuse; Nevertheless I considered it proper to let the subject stop with him, after this apology.
You will perceive by the numerous enclosures that I have enclosed to do upon me and throughout the proceedings have been anxious to discover if the abominable traffic of slave trade had been revived in American vessels which since the capital punishment of Captain Gordon by the United States Government I have not heard of a single shipment of slaves, from this part of the Coast and which previous to that event was almost exclusively carried on, most disgracefully, under the American Flag. I learn from the President of the Government Council that Baxter's
Baxter's trial will soon take place. I was surprised to hear him say that the penalty applicable to him by the Criminal laws of Portugal is very slight and very probably he will only receive a reprimand and be put at liberty. Should this take place I shall order him back to Prison, and keep him there four months for desertion, unless claimed in the meantime by the Master of the Barque "Governor Carver". I never met in all my life a more curt and consumate rouge than the said Edward Baxter. A man so regardless of himself and his Creator as to make several false claims only to injure Captain Mason of the "Governor Carver" who he himself has wronged by receiving advance money at St Helena and in a few days afterwards deserted at Mossamedes.
I would do an act of injustice if I closed this despatch without mentioning in an honorable manner, the able, prompt and willing cooperation, I received from the Government in assisting me to penetrate the truth of Baxter's representation and it is worthy of commendable honor to the Authorities
Authorities here to note the indignation which the story of Baxter aroused within them when their national honor was in danger of being stigmatized with the revival of the slave trade in their waters. I have the Honor
to be
Your Most Obedt Servant Augustus Archer Silva Commercial Agent

div1.p:
Sir
The Seaman who claimed the protection of this Commercial Agency as a destitute American Citizen, & who ran away from the American Barque "Governor Carver" at Mossamedes for the alleged reason that said vessel was a slaver, & who afterwards was shipped by you as a British Subject on board of the British Brig "Elizabeth" but detained on account of some irregularity; You will please send Seaman to this office, that he may explain to me why he claimed & received protection as an American Citizen, when he was not such & likewise to prove the charge made by
by him against the character of the American Barque "Governor Carver".

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be
Your Most Obedt Servant

div1.p:
Sir;
In accordance with the request contained in your despatch of Today's date, I have the honor to send to your Office the Seaman Edward Baxter, who left the American Barque "Governor Carver" at Mossamedes on the ground, as he alleges, that she was engaged in the slave trade.

When Baxter by your desire presented himself to me, a few days ago, I was under the impression that you had satisfied yourself that he was a British subject and intended to place him at my disposal with a view to my receiving his desposition. If I misunderstood your intentions and object you will I hope
hope accept the above explanation, as an excuse.

I enclose the declaration made by Baxter before me to enable you to ascertain whether the circumstances that he may relate to you coincide with those that he told to me, and you are at liberty if you think proper to take and use a copy of this statement.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your Most Obedient
humble Servant

div1.p: I Edward Baxter, a native of Liverpool, twenty-five years of age, do solemnly declare, and state as follows—

Towards the end of July, I shipped at St Helena on board the Barque "Governor Carver" belonging to Westport United States of America, of which vessel, Charles Mason, a native of Nantucket, is master. The first port at which the ship touched after leaving St Helena was Little Fish Bay, the arrival there on a Friday afternoon about three weeks ago. At about twelve OClock that night, four boats in one of which I was employed, was sent ashore to the North Point of the Bay and there embarked seventy five Blacks, whom they conveyed on board. The boats were then sent a second time to the same place, and as I was afraid of what they were doing, I ran away in the dark, as I shipped to go on
on a whaling voyage, and not to run slaves I cannot say what number of Blacks, they took the second time. The ship was fitted out like a whaler but when we were three days out from St Helena I saw Sperm whales all round the ship and said to the second Mate "how is it we are not lowering after those whales." "Oh", said he, "we are not after these kinds of whales," I then asked him what kind of whales we were after: he answered "we are after two or three hundred Black birds if we can catch them. Then the fourth day they lifted out the bodies-- The Americans call them "Tripods" and there was a kind of Bulk head- They knocked the bulkhead away and I saw an iron rod nailed down to the deck, with footcuffs a sort of handcuffs on the feet. Then the Captain said Boatswain do you know what these things are for "this is where we shall put the first seventy
seventy niggers we get" and it was there they put the seventy-five they brought on board that Friday night. After leaving the boat, I remained all night in the mountains, the Barque went away the following morning, steering towards the north. I then went down into the town, and saw the Captain of the schooner "Lincolnshire" whom I asked to give me a passage to Loanda; He told me to help to get the Bullocks on board, and then to go on board myself, I did so, and arrived at this port on the 24th of September.

postscript.p: Thus solemnly declared and stated before me at the British Consulate, Loanda this 6th Day of October 1865.

This is to certify that the above named Edward Baxter, being an illiterate person, the foregoing Statement was carefully read over to him; he appeared perfectly to understand the same and affixed his mark thereto in my presence.
A True copy of the original of record in this Consulate.

div1.p:
Sir;
This Honorable Consul of Government desires to request of you all the possible information respecting a seaman named Edward Baxter, who was found on board the English Brig "Elizabeth" when about to sail from this port without the legal and indespensible documents to enable him to leave this city. The said seaman states that he deserted from an American Barque that had taken in a cargo of slaves at Mossamedes and that he was willing to run such a risk ran away in that place and obtained a passage to this city on board the Steamer "Lincolnshire"

The Honorable Council of Government expects that you will kindly be pleased to furnish as much information as possible regarding said seaman
seaman and all particulars bearing on this subject.
God preserve you!
Secretary General's office at Loanda October 9th 1865

closer.signed: (Signed) Antonio de Mello Varajãs Government Secretary General

div1.p: I, Edward Baxter; a native of Liverpool employed in the commerce of the United States during the past four years as an American Seaman; do solemnly declare and state as follows:

About three years ago I left Boston, Mass. United States of America, on board the American "Eliza and Nell" bound for San Francisco; Arrived there and shipped on board the American Ship "Live Yankees" bound for Hong-Kong and for China. On arrival there re-entered said ship bound back to San Franshisco. and on said passage was captured by the Confederate privateer "Alabama"; was landed by said privateer at where I shipped on board the American Barque " bound for
for San Franchisco at which port I shipped on board the American Ship "Flying " to Shanghai then from said port on board said vessel bound for New York; Touched at the Island of St Helena, when on account of a pervious disagreement with the Captain, I got my discharge; How I shipped on board the American Barque "Govvernor Carver" of Westport, Rhode Island United States of America, where of Charles Mason was Master, and bound on a whaling cruise for which purpose I shipped as Boatswain and Boatsteerer Three days after leaving St Helena, I saw several whales round the ship and inquired of the second Mate "Why dont we lower after these whales?" He replied we arent after these kind of Whales" I
About 9 days out from St Helena stood off and on off Little Fish Bay for three days; Second day of said three days went on shore with two boats, about two miles south of Fort in said bay; Obtained about 40 barrels water, towed them off. Fourth day after sighting Little Fish Bay and thirteenth from St Helena, entered and dropped anchor in said bay, about two ships lengths from said Fort. When the Captian went on shore. Two Custom House Officers came on board but seeing no cargo on board left at about 9 Oclock Lay till about 11 oclock; when the boats returned, having the Captain ashore. Weighed anchor under command of Firt Mate and dropped it again in about half an hour after sailing that time in a northerly direction
direction which brought us off the North point of the bay. Lowered four boats and proceeded on shore, a little to the northward of said north point; I was on board the first boat which struck the shore commandded by the second Mate, where we met the Captain and Portuguese having in their possession, seventy five Negro Slaves, which we shipped on board said boats and from thence to said American Barque "Governor Carver" - Captain still on shore said slaves arms were secured hehind them by mean of grass ropes. On reaching the vessel the Tripots were removed and Bulkheads knocked away, and slaves were then unshackled to said bars, on doing which grass ropes were removed. The four boats again returned
returned to the shore; I being as before in second Mates' boat; Reached the shore where we again met the Captain and said companions; I saw a number of black men, but as to their being slaves, I cannot swear. Jumped out of the boat, my reason for which was demanded by the Mate My reply was to anser a call of Nature and taking advantage of this excuse, I ran away and hid in the hillds, till daybreak, when I ascended one of said hills and saw said American Barque "Governor Carver" getting under way, I saw her apparently to the northward under a good breeze, and, about 9 ocloc, she was nearly out of sight to the northward. Same day British Mail Steamer "Lincolnshire" arrived from Lisbon. ABout 12 oclock started for
for the town of Mossamedes; Little Fish bay, and there met on the beach Captain James of the said Steamer "Lincolnshire" from whom I asked a passage to Loanda where I could secure the protection of an American Consul. There being none in Mossamedes; He requested me to assist his men to hip some bullocks and then to go on board myself, which I did on same day. Do no remember whether it was same evening or next that the Steamer sailed for Loanda. During the disembarcation of said seventy five slaves, one of the Boatsteerers remarked that if procurable two hundres and fifty slaves would be shipped. Arrived at Loanda September 24th. immediately after which I landed and presented myself to
to the United States Commercail Agent who on hearing my statement, gave no protection, and during the from said date, till the 5th inst; was from day to day examined by him regarding preceeding statement and on one occasion was sent to the British Commissioner of the Slave Trade in this City for examination; I did not claim from him British protection, but in answer to a question of where I was born, I said I was by birth a native of Liverpool, England but that for several years I had been sailing under the American Flag, as an American sailor, and have had protection papers last of which was procured at New London, State of Connecticut United
United States of American, five years ago. The British Commissioner who is also British Consul, then said You are then an Englishman and as such I shall ship you on board the English Brig "Elizabeth" then in this port and sailing on the 4th inst. and into which vessel I so as accordingly ships , but previous to which, he gave me a despatch, which on arrival in England, I was to deliver to the Foreign Office in London and they would look after me. Owing to now complaince with some of the other regulations, I was taken from on board said Brig "Elizabeth" by the Portuguese authorities.
I still declare myself to be an American Citizen and as such ask American protection.

I do hereby solemnly declare and state, that all the foregoing statements are true, which I have declared in presence of three witnesses -- Namely -- Augustus E. B. Gover, Merchant, Native of Salem, Mass, United States of America. Isaac Barnett, Native of the Isle of Right, and Master of the British Barque "Eastward Ho" and Kirkman Finlay of Glasgow Scotland.
So help me God.
Done in triplicate at St Paul de Loanda on this the tenth day of October, One thousand, eight hundred and sixty five.

closer.signed:
Witnesses
Aug. E. B. Gover
Isaac Barnett
Kirkman Finlay

div1.p: Sworn before me this tenth day of October, in the year of Our Lord, One thousand, eight hundred, and Sixty-five, and I further certify that the above named Edward Baxter does not know how to read or write and that I have carefully read this document over to him and he has certified to the same by his mark in this my presence.

St Paul de Loanda Oct 10th 1865

div1.p:
Sir
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch of the 9th inst, requesting of me information regarding a report made by Edward Baxter, a run-away seaman of the American Whaling Barque, "Governor Carver" at Mossamedes to the effect said Barque did take in slaves while at anchor at Mossamedes, during the past month & for which reason said seaman Edward Baxter gave as an excuse for deserting said vessel.

I have the honor to forward you enclosed
enclosed, for the information of the Honorable Consul de Governs a copy of two depositions signed by him; One taken before the British Consul & the other before me by which it will be seen that the honor of Portugal as well as the United States is brought into question.

I most respectfully request of the Provincial Government to use all endeavors to search out the truth of the important case, that not only the honor of Portugal but also that of the United States may be indicated I therefore propose that said seaman be sent to Mossamedes as I think on the spot the Provincial Government, will have a better opportunity to judge the true merits of the case & better qualify me to bring to the notice of the United States Government a
his representative. I felt apprehension of his veracity & therefore adopted a of indifference towards him & employed him with some light work about my house.

From day to day I would question & crop question him closely about the circumstances connected with the Barque "Governor Carver" with a to compare one statement with another. It was also with this intention I sent him to you as Commissioner of the mixed Commission" that you also might extract from him information to compare afterwards with that he furnished me.

I must confess I was somewhat surprised when I learned at a late hour that you had shipped him as a British subject on board of the British Brig "Elizabeth" & I am glad to note in your despatch of yesterday that your action was unintentional, although I gave
gave you no cause whatever for you to suppose I had done with him. My mind was rehired of a grand responsibility when it came to my knowledge that for some slight error of Police regulation Baxter was taken out of the Brig Elizabeth by the Portuguese Authorities before she went to seas. You also much be well aware that such a grave subject as the charge made against the America Barque "Governor Carver" my Government will look to me for explanation.

Last examining in the presence of important witnesses, I took the deposition of said Edward Baxter, on the charge prepared by him against the character of the Barque "Governor Carver" I enclose you a copy, which will prove to you the groungs whcih justify me in handing said Baxter over to the Provincial Government for them, at my request to thoroughly investigate this important case
that the honor alike of Portugal & the United States now involved, may be properly vindicated & better qualify me to bring the case to the notice of my Government

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be
Your Most Obedt Servant
closer.signed:
Signed Augustus Archer Silva
Commercial Agent

div1.p:
Sir
Aggreeable to the wish of the New "Consular de Governo" I have the honor to send on board of your ship, Seaman Edward Baxter who deserted from the American Whaling Barque "Governor Carver" at Mossamedes.

You are well aware of the object of his presence of board of your ship and I heop his testimony at Mossamedes may serve to clear up the mystery which now hangs over the character of said American Barque and the authorities of that place.

div1.p:
Sir
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch of the 10th inst. enclosing a certified copy of the deposition made before you by Edward Baxter, a seaman who deserted from the American Barque "Governor Carver" on the pretext that she had shipped a cargo of slaves
As I understand you to claim Baxter as a deserter from an American ship. I can have neither the right nor have I the slightest desire to contest the claim.

I have the honor to enclose a certified copy of the statement made in my presence by Baxter of the alleged shipment of slaves, and I take the opportunity
opportunity of observing that it is entirely flase that any conversation of the nature took place between us, declared by him in his despositions.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your most obedient
humble Servant.

div1.p:
Sir;
Having returned from Mossamedes where I conveiged the United States Citizen Edward Baxter for the purpose of ascertaining the truth of a statement made by him of a shipment of slaves having been effected on the Bay of Mossamedes. I have to inform you that the Governor of that district, co-operating with me, enclosed with a minute inquiry in presence of several persons and of Edward Baxter himself without sharing any effort that might tend to the discovery of the truth.
From the results of these investigation which are now submitted to the Hon Consul of Government to become evidents that the statement is a false one.

Said Edward Baxter whereby contradicts his statements in various instances and proves from his own witness the falsity of several points set forth in his statement. The fact that becomes evident is that
whether from not agreeing with the Captain of the Barque "Governor Carver" or because he may have been punished for his misconduct and deserted the vessel remaining some days in the neighborhood of the town eating and sleeping in different houses whose owners he afterwards pointed out as being in conspiracy with the Captain of the vessel at the time of shipping the slaves and to whom he had said that it was easier to cut his throat than to return on board the ship he had deserted for the reason that he was on very bad terms with the Captain, and it was only after the vessel had sailed that he went to the town where he slept one night.

Whether in revenge to the Captain or from any other bad feeling, the said Edward Baxter has made a fake statement involving not only the authorities, but also several individuals some of which have been detained and are now awaiting their
trial, that had to be instituted for having been pointed out by him as having assisted the Captain in shipping the slaves as he had related.
God preserve you!

closer.dateline:
Ship Infanto D. Soao at anchor in the
Port of Loanda 30th October 1865.

address.addrLine: Commercial Agent of the United States

div1.p:
Sir
The Council of Government acting as Governor General of this Province has much pleasure in informing you that from the inquiries instituted at Mossamedes by the Governor of that district, it has been most authentically proved that the accusation of the seaman Edward Baxter of the American Barque "Governor Carver" alluded to in your despatch of the 10th October, is a false one.

The accusation is of the gravest character, affirming that a shipment of slaves had been effected close to that town. Said seaman is therefore a Prisoner according to our Criminal Code of Laws and will consequently be tried and punished for which purpose he is already in Jail.

The
The Council of Government has to thank you for your services in producing said seaman thus facilitating this discovery of the truth, alike important to the Portuguese Nation and the United States of America; But you will yet render greater service, if you should arrange in such a way as to cause said Barque to come to this Port, at an early date, by addressing through the Governor of that place, an order to all American Whalers calling there, in order that notice may be conveyed to her, so as to identify the seaman.
God preserve you!

closer.dateline: Palace of the Government at Loanda Novr 1st 1865

(Signed) Luis José Mendes Affouso
President of Council of Government

div1.p:
Sir
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch of yesterday's date wherein I am informed that the despositions of the American Seaman, Edward Baxter, taken at Mossamedes proved by authenticated evidence that the accusation made by him against the people of that place and the character of the American Barque "Governor Carver" was false.

Reserving my comments on this subject, for a subsequent opportunity. I have only to remind your Excellency, that I claim the right, to respectfully request of you, the kindness to furnish and at your earliest convenience with copies of all the depositions taken
taken at Mossamedes by the Authorities of that place, that I may be enabled not only to express to you my views on this subject but also to possess myself with information that I may represent clearly the case to my Government.

Your Excellency will have the goodness to understand that this Agency does not approve of the manner in which Edward Baxter has slandered the honor of Portugal on Portuguese Territory but it reserves for itself the right to throughly investigate the case on the part of the United States Government in which light I have the honor to request the despositions herein named.

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be
Your most Obedt Servant

div1.p:
Sir,
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch of the 3rd inst, in which you request copies of the depositions taken at Mossamedes to the supposed shipment of slaves in the proximity of that town, as stated in this city by the seaman Edward Baxter, a naturalized American.

In answer I have to inform you that those docts are four in number and very voluminous. That at the time you asked for them the originals had already been sent to the respective Judge, for him, within 8 days, to pronounce verdict upon the charge brought against that seaman for false statement- This has now been done and intimated to the culprit in accordance with the Commercial Treaty between the United States of America and Portugal. That in the mean time said
said seaman has withdrawn his former statements, as false and in public audience as is shown from the enclosed desposition, which I have the honor to hand you.

I believe this document will dispense with those requested in your said despatch, which clearly proves the falsity of the accusation. This is more than proved by his spontaneous and voluntary confession.
Nevertheless if you still consider them indespensible they will be sent to you, as soon as copies can be taken by the Court.
God preserve you!

div1.p:
Geliciano Gonçales de Espirito Santo Gorrha clerk to the judge of the Criminal Court in this district &c. I certify being the clerk in court during the proceedings in investigating the truth of an accusation made by the American Seaman Edward Baxter before the judicial Authorities of this place of a shipment of slaves in the Bay of Mossamedes in which record of page 45, an inquiry is seen as follows- Terms of Inquiry- In the year of our Lord 1865, on the 4th day of November, in the City of Loanda and in the Criminal Court of the district, present Dr. Carlos Pechero de Bettencourt judge of the Criminal Court with exercise in both sectors of this tribunal together with me Geliciao Gonçales de Espirito Gorrha clerk and the Prisoner Edward Baxter for the purpose of being to examine &C. This was performed in the following manner In
In the presence of the witnesses Luis Pedro Tenina and José Antonio de Santos Public Officers of the Court who gave oath before Judge to verify the , in writing the questions and answers and through the interpreters Francisco da Potico Marquis Cortez a Merchant of this place whose oath was taken by the Judge to faithfully translate and transmit to the prisoner, the questions made by the Judge and to me the answers given by him, which he promised to fulfill. Thus through the said interpreter, the Judge inquired of the prisoner his name, place of birth, age, name of father, condition in life, profession, last situation, if he had ever before been in prison, and if he enjoys the liberty of his occupation to which, he replied then his name was Edward Baxter- Native of Liverpool- age 25 years- a son of John and Mary Baxter- married-
married- a seaman and that he enjoys the liberty of his profession- that his last residence was at Mossamedes from where he came to this city having remained there only a short time- and that he had never been in prison before- being further questioned by the judge as to his nationality he answered that he was an American Citizen having been naturalized as such about one year ago; He, the said prisoner then addressing the interpreter said that the accusation made by him both to the American and British Consul and to the Government of this Province, of a shipment of slaves made in the Bay of Mossamedes on board the American Barque "Governor Carver" was false and that he declared it to be such to the Judge; whereupon being asked by the Judge for what purpose he had made such a statement, He replied, that having deserted the said Barque, and
and fearing future punishment he had invented that means not only to avoid it but also in the hopes of obtaining a passage gratis to England and it was with those views that on his arrival here he applied to his Consul Mr Silva.

All the above statements having to be made known the Judge caused this record to be drawn out and after being read and explained to the prisoner, by the interpreter was signed by both together with the witnesses and myself the clerk signing for the prisoner he not knowing how to read or write- and- I, Feliciano Gonçales de Espirito Santo Gorrha- Bettencourt Francisco de Silva Marquis Porto - Luis Pedro Tenina - José Antonio de Santos.

No more was contained in said interrogation, of which I have caused a true and faithful certified copy to be taken from the
the original documents, in my possession which has been compared and signed by me and filed according to law. Loanda November 8th 1865- I, Feliciano Gonçales de Esperito Santo e Gorrha Clerk who have written and signed it, and confirmed by us- José Solomao de Lewis Perticoine Batathe and Feliciano Gonçales de Esperito Santo e Gorrha

closer.signed: (Signed) Antonio de Mello Varajao Government Secretary

opener.dateline:
United States Commercial Agency
St Paul de Loanda Nov 20 1865

div1.p:
Sir,
I have the honor to request of you the kindness to deliver the enclosed letter to Captain Charles Mason of the American Barque "Governor Carver", when his vessel enters your port and who I understand, is cruizing off your Coast.

The recent unfortunate circumstance connected with the false accusation made by Edward Baxter against the inhabitants of your quiet village and the reputation of Barque "Governor Carver", was received here with doubt by everyone and his subsequent confession was no more than was generally anticipated.

It
It must have been extremely unpleasant to the inhabitants of Mossamedes and particularly to yourself to have your character defamed by the base accusation of having the slave trade revived at your very door more especially at a time when it had become a fixed fact that for so many years no instance of this nefarious nature has been recorded but on the contrary, your district has flourished by ircreased Commercial and agricultural prosperity, to the great admiration of all interested in the welfare of Angola.

I have already exchanged congratulations with the Govt Consulho de Governo for the happy termination of this disagreeable case; I also expressed to them my thanks for this cordial cooperation and promptness of action which had the final results to force from Edward Baxter his voluntary confession; I am not that
that a portion of this credit belongs to you and you will please accept the acknowledgement of my warmest sentiments.

I have written my government a minute description of the whole case and I am confident they will appreciate the able manner in which the authorities of this province defended the innocence of the American Barque "Governor Carver"

closer.salute:
I have the Honor
To be
Your most obedt Servant

opener.dateline:
United States Commercial Agency
St Paul de Loanda Nov 20th 1865

div1.p:
Sir;
On the 24th of September, Edward Baxter, styling himself an American Seaman, presented himself to this Commercial Agency for protection, and on oath, before witnesses declared that, he ran away from your vessel at Little Fish Bay, for the reason that you had shipped, at that place, a cargo of slaves.

This report, very naturally created much excitement and anxiety with the Local Portuguese Authorities and myself, who proceeded at once to investigate the truth. Baxter was examined by the Authorities of this place and by the British Consul also and at my request was sent to Little Fish Bay on board of the Portuguese Corvette "Infanto de Soao" which
which vessel left here October 12th and returned on the 30th of the same month, on which day, I received a communication from the Commander, informing me that Baxter failed to prove on the alleged suit the accusation he had made against your vessel and the inhabitants of that industrious village. Baxter was then, by order of the Portuguese Government, imprisoned. A few days after he was brought before the Judicial Tribunal of this City and indicted with the charge of having made false accusation and ordered again to prison, to await his trial. Baxter, before the court, became alarmed and to a Portuguese gentleman he confessed that everything he had said was false and a pure invention of his own. He was brought again before the Judge and made a formal confession of which I have the honor to enclose a copy. Baxter is still in Prison waiting his trial. The acting Governor General told me a few days ago that the
the penalty of his crime, by the criminal laws of Portgual was very light and that he would only be reprimanded and set at Liberty. As soon as this takes place, I shall order Baxter back to Prison and there confine him four months, on the charge of having deserted your vessel and I hope, in the meantime, you will come to Loanda to claim him. Your presence here will also do much good. I have been requested by the Governor General of this Province to invite you to visit this Port.

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be
Your Most Obedt Servt
